selected_quotes: The urgency of providing urban green infrastructure increases as climate change makes our cities hotter.
Landscaping low on list of priorities.Cambridge has new transport schemes designed with no ref. to context: heritage g…
Why are City Planners cautious about Urban Greening? #greeninfrastructure
Why don't planners embrace green infrastructure?
What is stopping planners from making 'green' cities? #gogreen

citation.abstract: It seems like a 'no brainer' to use urban greening to help cities adapt to increasing heat, but the uptake of green infrastructure, such as trees and vegetated roofs, surfaces and walls, is slow. Why?
citation.title: If planners understand it's cool to green cities, what's stopping them?

news.title: If planners understand it's cool to green cities, what's stopping them?
news.summary: Our cities are getting hotter, more crowded and noisier. Climate change is bringing more heatwaves, placing pressure on human health, urban amenity, productivity and infrastructure.

news.title: Urban jungle to ease the heat
news.summary: Our cities are getting hotter, more crowded and noisier. Climate change is bringing more heatwaves, placing pressure on human health, urban amenity, productivity and infrastructure.

news.summary: Our cities are getting hotter, more crowded and noisier. Climate change is bringing more heatwaves, placing pressure on human health, urban amenity, productivity and infrastructure.

news.title: Building cool cities for a hot future
news.summary: Another hot and humid day in Sydney tomorrow with a maximum of 32 degrees in the city and 38 in the western suburbs.

news.title: Building cool cities for a hot future
news.summary: (via noodls) / Design decisions impact the urban microclimate, and ultimately our health and wellbeing, write Paul Osmond and Jonathan Fox.

news.title: Here’s how green infrastructure can easily be added to the urban planning toolkit
news.summary: Urban planners are wary of green infrastructure, although they generally understand its benefits, as our recent Conversation article showed.

news.title: Why ‘green cities’ need to become a deeply lived experience
news.summary: Australian cities are inherently diverse places, but that diversity can lead to conflict between different values about what cities should and can be.

news.title: Biophilic urbanism: how rooftop gardening soothes souls
news.summary: What do an engineer, a building surveyor and a mental health nurse have in common? The answer is a retrofitted rooftop garden.

news.title: Higher-density cities need greening to stay healthy and liveable
news.summary: Access to high-quality public open space is a key ingredient of healthy, liveable cities.

news.title: More than just drains: recreating living streams through the suburbs
news.summary: Lot sizes and backyards are shrinking in Australia at the same time as building density is increasing.
